title: Why was Timurlane so cruel? Was he as cruel as the Mongols at his time? - Quora

Was Timur as cruel as the Mongols at his time? Hard to say. By the time that Timur rose to power, the Mongols were not really as powerful anymore. The Yuan Dynasty had pretty much been driven out of China. The Ilkhanate had ceased to exist. The Golden Horde was divided. The Chagatai Khanate had been subjugated by Timur.  The world map in the year 1400 AD. Note that the Mongol Khanates are not really in a position of power anymore. The only powerful Mongol leader at the time of Timur was Tokhtamysh of the Golden Horde. So let’s compare Timur and Tokhtamysh to see who was more cruel. Tokhtamysh besieged the city of Moscow in 1382. After his men overcame the defenses and entered the city, around 24,000 people were killed in the massacre. Tokhtamysh also invaded the Caucasus region and sacked Tabriz in 1385–1386. This campaigns seem to have been just as ruthless as Timur’s campaigns. He may have taken as many as 200,000 slaves from the Caucasus. The city of Tabriz fared little better. So it doesn’t really seem like Timur was anymore or less cruel than the Mongols of his time. The difference mostly lay in the inability of the Mongols to carry out such conquests anymore. On the other hand, Timur was able to do so. So Timur would overall have more acts of cruelty, as a part of his war tactics, than the Mongols did. Individually these acts seem no more or less cruel than those of the Mongols. The main difference lies in the inability of the Mongols to conquer anymore as Timur did.  Tamerlane It must also be noted that Timur’s army contained a great number of Mongols. The central core of his army was the Chagatai Ulus. So it is safe to assume that the Mongols (Chagatai) took part in the massacres and such ordered by Timur. Was Timur as cruel as the Mongols during their conquests in the 12th century? I would say kind of. The Mongol Empire clearly beats him on the numbers. He doesn’t even have half the casualties that the Mongols did. However, both committed similar acts of cruelty on multiple occasions. The Mongols just did it more often. The acts of cruelty themselves were quite similar.  Hulagu’s Sack of Baghdad  Timur’s Sack of Isfahan. Doesn’t really seem all that different. Why was Timur so cruel? There are probably several reasons that resulted in Timur being able to carry out such cruel actions. Here are some of the major ones: Timur was born in Transoxiana in the 14th century. This was a region that was under the control of the remnants of the Chagatai Khanate, including the Barlas tribe that Timur belonged to. Timur also spent his childhood in this region and grew up here. Unfortunately, very little is known of his childhood. However, it is safe to assume that Timur did not grow up with a sense of morality like ours. He would have grown up with a far different moral compass. A moral compass that was followed by the Turko-Mongols of Central Asia, much of which was set forth by Genghis Khan. So trying to apply our modern compass to someone like Timur or Genghis doesn’t really make any sense. It doesn’t seem as if Genghis Khan believed that he did anything wrong. His moral compass was simply far too different from out own. Another thing to consider is that the nomadic ways of waging war are generally more ruthless and cruel than those of the settled civilizations (for the most past). What may seem to us like a very cruel way of waging war, might have been seen as perfectly normal to the nomads of Central Asia.Let’s not forget that Central Asia still followed the laws and culture set forth by Genghis Khan. The people of the region still followed the ways of Genghis Khan.Tamerlane had a hero that he seemed to have respected quite a bit. He wanted to emulate that man and his accomplishments. This man was Genghis Khan. So it really should not be surprising that a man that considered Genghis as a hero would have no problem carrying out similar acts.Timur was an opportunist. A man willing to take advantage of anything to achieve his goals. Morality never seemed to have been very high on his list.Timur, like Genghis before him, weaponized fear and cruelty. Most acts of cruelty had a reason behind them. They were to serve some purpose. It was not really cruelty for the sake of it. It was usually for the sake of pragmatism. Look at his execution of 50,000–100,000 captives overnight, prior to the war against the Delhi Sultanate. There was actually a reason behind it. During an earlier conflict, the captives had cheered on the forces of the Delhi Sultanate. Timur believed that a battle could not be fought with a hundred thousand captives in the Timurid camp. They were likely to break free and join the Delhi Sultanate forces. So he gave the order to execute them all. The Sack of Isfahan is a similar example. The city had initially surrendered to Timur and then killed his guards (around six thousand) and tax collectors within the city. The city was massacred to serve as a clear example to every other city in the empire.Another purpose of these cruel acts was to make people surrender without a fight. Many cities would surrender to Timur without fighting, so as not to risk his wrath.
